author: Marianna Papadakis
title: Over 60pc of law students want to practice law despite grim market
text:
Fewer female law graduates want to become barristers because of the perceived higher pressure of the job. Jessica Shapiro by Marianna Papadakis More than 60 per cent of all graduates being pumped out of law schools aim to become practising lawyers, but the industry is struggling to absorb the oversupply in graduate numbers .
Around 61 per cent of law graduates want to practice law when they finish their degree, while around 28 per cent were uncertain about their future careers and 11 per cent had no intention of becoming lawyers.
A perceived future in law remains gender segmented with between 37 per cent and 38 per cent of female graduates saying the main reason they did not intend to practice as barristers was because there was too much stress and they did not have the required skills.
Other reasons included that they did not have enough information to make a decision and because the bar was not family-friendly but rather higher risk because they work for themselves.
The study involved 1403 graduates from university law schools and the College of Law in NSW and was undertaken by the Women Lawyers' Association of NSW to assess the career intentions of graduates and the effectiveness of initiatives targeting diversity, retention of talent and leadership in the legal profession.
Male students were more likely to want to study law because of perceptions of prestige, gaining a good income and having an interest in government and politics, while female graduates wanted to study law because of an interest in social justice, and previously studied legal studies at school and enjoyed mock trials and debating.
Women Lawyers' Association of NSW president Lee-May Saw said when considered in the context of the current employment market for law graduates, the survey pointed to a real need for initiatives, policies, practices and programs to be reviewed starting from when students were studying law at university.
